Situation1: They occasionally participate in family traditions during holidays and gatherings.
Situation2: They identify a malfunctioning pool filtration system that could endanger swimmers’ safety if not repaired immediately.
Story: I stared at my phone, my mom’s message lighting up the screen: “Don’t forget, we’re all waiting for you to help set up for the family dinner tonight. Grandma’s counting on you to bring the candles for the ceremony.” My heart squeezed a little. Every year, I was the one who lit the candles, the one who made Grandma smile. But as I glanced up from the locker room, the hum of the pool’s filtration system was off—too quiet. I checked the control panel and my stomach dropped. The system was malfunctioning, and if I didn’t get it fixed, the water could become unsafe for swimmers. My supervisor was out for the day, and I was the only one who knew how to handle the maintenance. I could already hear my family’s disappointment if I didn’t show up, but I also felt the weight of responsibility for everyone who trusted me to keep them safe here. My hands trembled as I weighed the expectations—my family’s tradition or my duty as a lifeguard.
